events.title: Forbidden Unions and Honored Vows: Catholicism, Indigenous Marital Norms, and Female Authority in Central Mexico during the Sixteenth and Seventeenth Centuries
events.description: AbstractAlthough formal political power lay largely in the hands of men, elite Nahua noblewomen in the pre-Hispanic period were able to exercise significant power behind the scenes by drawing on their position as go-betweens in marriage alliances between ruling-class families. During the colonial period, these women's access to traditional forms of
events.speaker: Clio Isaacson

events.description: “The Rahaeng Road: Fighting Monsoon Time and Teak Time in the China, Burma, India Theater”Michael MandelkornBurma was colonized by the British largely through the military cooption of commercial infrastructure set up for teak extraction. events.title: Confessions of a Justified Madman: Truth, Lies, and the South African War
events.description: Pre-Circulated PaperThe pre-circulated paper is available one week prior to the workshop to the Princeton University community via SharePoint. All others should request a copy of the paper by emailing Emmanuel Ennin.To request disability-related accommodations, please email Jackie Wasneski at least a week in advance

events.title: Switzerland and Poverty: Looking for the Enlightenment Origins of the Social Question
events.description: The willingness to put an end to poverty is usually considered a novelty of the 19th century, but it was actually a major Enlightenment theme. This new project aims to investigate the continuities and ruptures in how poverty was conceptualized and addressed in Switzerland during the Sattelzeit (1750-1850), interrogating the legacy of Enlightenment
events.speaker: Damiano Bardelli

events.title: Bringing 'Law and Order to the Crude Frontier': The Limits of Territorial Law in the Western Great Lakes, 18231830
events.description: AbstractFollowing British capitulation in the War of 1812, the U.S. established a series of forts to consolidate federal authority in the "Old Northwest," but bridging the gap between military occupation and civil legal order would prove to be more of a challenge. This chapter examines the arrival of James Duane Doty in 1823, the man credited with
events.speaker: The Limits of Territorial Law in the Western Great Lakes, 18231830

events.title: Anya Bernstein, "Pleistocene Park: Engineering Wilderness in a More-than-Human World"
events.description: Pleistocene Park is a large-scale science experiment in Arctic Siberia in the form of a future-oriented rewilding project with the goal of mitigating climate change. The Park’s creators hypothesize that introducing large herbivores into the area will slow the thawing of permafrost. Using the approach of multispecies ethnography, in attending to the
events.speaker: Anya Bernstein; Harvard University

events.title: Theorizing, Inventing, and Contesting a Place for Development: Appalachia in the War on Poverty, 19651973
events.description: AbstractDoes development need poverty to legitimize and justify itself? The economist John Kenneth Galbraith might scoff at the question; he linked the two tightly in arguing that it was precisely a new attention to the persistence and spread of global poverty that gave rise to the development paradigm’s dominance at midcentury. Galbraith was perha
events.speaker: Caroline West

events.title: Labor, Liberty, and Living Racial Capitalism: Enslaved Women and Daily Life in an 18th-century French Port City
events.description: Racial capitalism was a daily practice for enslaved men and women, who mostly arriving as teenagers to Nantes, France’s largest slave port. Often apprenticed to white artisans and living in their households, enslaved women in particular lived in constant negotiation with residents of all ranks. They engaged in essential productive and reproductive
events.speaker: Julie Hardwick

events.title: A Third Path: Corporatism in Brazil and Portugal
events.description: A Third Path delves into the pivotal yet understudied corporatist experiments of Brazil and Portugal during the 1930s. In the aftermath of the Great Depression, these nations sought a "third path" between laissez-faire capitalism and communism, expanding government powers to regulate labor and production by integrating economic and social groups in
events.speaker: Melissa Teixeira

events.title: Book Talk: Domestic Nationalism: Muslim Women, Health and Modernity in Indonesia
events.description: Domestic Nationalism argues that Muslim women in Java and Sumatra, from the late 1910s to the 1950s, were central to Indonesia’s progress as guardians and promoters of health and piety through gendered activities of care work. Women from all walks of life were called upon to fulfill domestic and motherly roles for the production and socialization o
events.speaker: Chiara Formichi
